questions.question: Which one statement is true? On the grounds of imaging appearances alone, the diagnosis is...
questions.learning_points:
The image shows right lower zone consolidation. It is not possible to establish the cause without reference to the clinical scenario which is not stated.
Consolidation can be caused by pneumonia, lung cancer, pulmonary oedema, or pulmonary haemorrhage/contusion. Alveolar proteinosis is a very rare cause. Both pulmonary oedema and alveolar proteinosis tend to cause more widespread bilateral consolidation. Any of the other causes are possible causes of the consolidation seen in this image.

questions.question: What congenital abnormality is visible in this chest X-ray of a patient with no respiratory symptoms?
options: Dextrocardia with bronchiectasis related to Kartagener’s syndrome
questions.learning_points:
The heart is on the right indicating dextrocardia. The liver and the stomach/colon bubble are in their normal positions indicating situs solitus (normal location of the abdominal viscera).
If the liver had been on the left and the stomach bubble on the right this would indicate situs inversus.
The lack of respiratory symptoms makes bronchiectasis related to Kartagener’s  syndrome unlikely.

questions.question: Which structure is visibly normal in this patient with lung cancer?
questions.learning_points:
The right paratracheal stripe is well-defined and is not widened; this line can be widened if there is right paratracheal lymph node enlargement.
Both hila are enlarged and there is nodular consolidation in the left upper and lower zones.

questions.question: 2 Images: Patient with lung cancer. Image 1 shows a right hilar mass. What complication has occurred at the time of image 2 which was acquired 4 months after image 1?
questions.learning_points:
Image 2 shows the right hilar mass has enlarged. The right hemidiaphragm is raised indicating phrenic nerve palsy due to compression or erosion by the mass.
There is no visible pleural effusion or pneumothorax.

questions.question: Patient with cough and fever. Which area is abnormal?
questions.learning_points: Consolidation is seen in the left lower zone; compare with the right lower zone and other areas of the lungs which are clear.

questions.question: Which structure is abnormal?
questions.learning_points: All structures are normal. This is a normal chest X-ray.

questions.question: Longstanding heavy smoker with a dry cough. Which statement is true?
options: Blunting of the costophrenic angles is due to pleural effusions
The patient is rotated to their right
The smoking history is irrelevant to interpretation of this image
questions.learning_points:
The costophrenic angles are blunted. This is because the lungs are hyperexpanded, as indicated by the flattened diaphragm, rather than because there are pleural effusions.
If anything, the patient is slightly rotated to the left.
The heart is not enlarged.
The smoking history is relevant to chest X-ray interpretation; the diagnosis of emphysema cannot be made in patients with hyperexpanded lungs unless the smoking history is known.

questions.question: 2 IMAGES: Rapid onset shortness of breath and chest pain. A previous chest X-ray is shown for reference (image 2). Regarding image 1, which statement is FALSE?
options: The upper zone vessels are enlarged
The previous image is irrelevant to interpretation of this image
The image is of adequate quality
The diagnosis is consistent with heart failure
questions.correct_answer: The previous image is irrelevant to interpretation of this image
questions.learning_points:
The previous image (image 2) shows the heart was enlarged. The previous image is relevant to chest X-ray interpretation and should be viewed as a matter of routine whenever interpreting a chest X-ray.
Image 1 shows classic features of severe pulmonary oedema; the upper zone vessels are enlarged indicating pulmonary venous hypertension, bilateral shadowing indicates alveolar oedema, and bilateral costophrenic blunting indicates pleural effusions.
The combination of severe pulmonary oedema in a patient with previously documented cardiomegaly is consistent with the diagnosis of heart failure.

questions.question: A chest drain has been inserted to treat a large pneumothorax and a chest X-ray was requested to check its position. Which feature does the X-ray show?
options: Inadequate image – the X-ray should be repeated
questions.learning_points:
The chest drain is not fully inserted into the thoracic cavity and placement has been complicated by extensive surgical emphysema over the left side of the chest.
The heart appears enlarged but the image is Anterior-Posterior (AP) so the heart size cannot be assessed accurately.
Although the right costophrenic angle is not included on the image there is no clear reason to retake the X-ray as the clinical question has been answered.

questions.question: A 78-year-old woman remains in hospital 4 weeks after a stroke with residual poor swallow. She becomes short of breath with a cough, high temperature and raised inflammatory markers; none of these clinical features were present at the time of admission. The X-ray appearances are most likely caused by which complication?
questions.learning_points:
The image shows dense consolidation in the lower zones, worse on the left.
In this clinical context the most likely cause is an aspiration pneumonia.
The lack of the clinical features described at the time of admission rules out a community acquired pneumonia.
Heart failure could cause these appearances but the cough, high temperature, and raised inflammatory markers point towards a respiratory tract infection.
There is no evidence of lung fibrosis or surgical emphysema.
